Dealing with multiple files

Source: vignettes/articles/multiple-files.Rmd
multiple-files.Rmd

Some googledrive functions are built to naturally handle multiple files, while others operate on a single file.

Functions that expect a single file:

  • drive_browse()
  • drive_cp()
  • drive_download()
  • drive_ls()
  • drive_mkdir()
  • drive_mv()
  • drive_rename()
  • drive_update()
  • drive_upload()

Functions that allow multiple files:

  • drive_publish()
  • drive_reveal()
  • drive_rm()
  • drive_share()
  • drive_trash()

In general, the principle is: if there are multiple parameters that are likely to vary across multiple files, the function is designed to take a single input. In order to use these function with multiple inputs, use them together with your favorite approach for iteration in R. Below is a worked example, focusing on tools in the tidyverse, namely the map() functions in purrr.

Upload multiple files, then rename them

Scenario: we have multiple local files we want to upload into a folder on Drive. Then we regret their original names and want to rename them.

Load packages.

library(googledrive)
library(glue)
library(tidyverse)

Upload

Use the example files that ship with googledrive. This looks a bit odd, but the first call returns their names and the second returns full paths on the local system.

local_files <- drive_example() %>% 
  drive_example()
basename(local_files)
#> [1] "chicken.csv" "chicken.jpg" "chicken.pdf" "chicken.txt"

Create a folder on your Drive and upload all files into this folder by iterating over the local_files using purrr::map().

folder <- drive_mkdir("upload-into-me-article-demo")
#> Created Drive file:
#>   * upload-into-me-article-demo: 1I3xJXlT4Jany4LywLKuV14z99cXa0zrO
#> with MIME type:
#>   * application/vnd.google-apps.folder
files <- map(local_files, ~ drive_upload(.x, path = folder, verbose = FALSE))

First, letâ€™s confirm that we uploaded the files into the new folder.

drive_ls(folder)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   name        id                                drive_resource   
#> * <chr>       <chr>                             <list>           
#> 1 chicken.txt 1O-VkK3hTTkM5hHzWAhqBOnbBqX3avfWf <named list [38]>
#> 2 chicken.pdf 18IVE8v-3jW_3iFiKuBNfb-yHFeG3Ri7_ <named list [38]>
#> 3 chicken.jpg 1V_9qKSAnhgMog-V-EGTG86XQ9Bt2ymVd <named list [40]>
#> 4 chicken.csv 1qIA7Of2VIGhG4uggfhuFCzTAqYFIHdAG <named list [38]>

Now letâ€™s reflect on the files object returned by this operation. files is a list of dribbles, one per uploaded file.

str(files, max.level = 1)
#> List of 4
#>  $ :Classes 'dribble', 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame': 1 obs. of  3 variables:
#>  $ :Classes 'dribble', 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame': 1 obs. of  3 variables:
#>  $ :Classes 'dribble', 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame': 1 obs. of  3 variables:
#>  $ :Classes 'dribble', 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame': 1 obs. of  3 variables:

This would be a favorable data structure if youâ€™ve got more map()ing to do, as youâ€™ll see below.

But what if not? You can always row bind individual dribbles into one big dribble yourself with, e.g., dplyr::bind_rows().

bind_rows(files)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   name        id                                drive_resource   
#>   <chr>       <chr>                             <list>           
#> 1 chicken.csv 1qIA7Of2VIGhG4uggfhuFCzTAqYFIHdAG <named list [38]>
#> 2 chicken.jpg 1V_9qKSAnhgMog-V-EGTG86XQ9Bt2ymVd <named list [40]>
#> 3 chicken.pdf 18IVE8v-3jW_3iFiKuBNfb-yHFeG3Ri7_ <named list [38]>
#> 4 chicken.txt 1O-VkK3hTTkM5hHzWAhqBOnbBqX3avfWf <named list [38]>

Below we show another way to finesse this by using a variant of purrr::map() that does this for us, namely map_df().

Rename

Imagine that we now wish these file names had a date prefix. First, form the new names. We use glue::glue() for string interpolation but you could also use paste(). Second, we map over two inputs: the list of dribbles from above and the vector of new names.

(new_names <- glue("{Sys.Date()}_{basename(local_files)}"))
#> 2019-08-16_chicken.csv
#> 2019-08-16_chicken.jpg
#> 2019-08-16_chicken.pdf
#> 2019-08-16_chicken.txt
files_dribble <- map2_df(files, new_names, drive_rename)
#> File renamed:
#>   * chicken.csv -> 2019-08-16_chicken.csv
#> File renamed:
#>   * chicken.jpg -> 2019-08-16_chicken.jpg
#> File renamed:
#>   * chicken.pdf -> 2019-08-16_chicken.pdf
#> File renamed:
#>   * chicken.txt -> 2019-08-16_chicken.txt

We use purrr::map2_df() to work through files, the list of dribbles (= Drive files), and new_names, the vector of new names, and row bind the returned dribbles into a single dribble holding all files.

Letâ€™s check on the contents of this folder again to confirm the new names:

drive_ls(folder)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   name                   id                                drive_resource  
#> * <chr>                  <chr>                             <list>          
#> 1 2019-08-16_chicken.txt 1O-VkK3hTTkM5hHzWAhqBOnbBqX3avfWf <named list [39â€¦
#> 2 2019-08-16_chicken.pdf 18IVE8v-3jW_3iFiKuBNfb-yHFeG3Ri7_ <named list [39â€¦
#> 3 2019-08-16_chicken.jpg 1V_9qKSAnhgMog-V-EGTG86XQ9Bt2ymVd <named list [40â€¦
#> 4 2019-08-16_chicken.csv 1qIA7Of2VIGhG4uggfhuFCzTAqYFIHdAG <named list [38â€¦

Letâ€™s confirm that, by using map2_df() instead of map2(), we got a single dribble back, instead of a list of one-row dribbles:

files_dribble
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   name                   id                                drive_resource  
#>   <chr>                  <chr>                             <list>          
#> 1 2019-08-16_chicken.csv 1qIA7Of2VIGhG4uggfhuFCzTAqYFIHdAG <named list [38â€¦
#> 2 2019-08-16_chicken.jpg 1V_9qKSAnhgMog-V-EGTG86XQ9Bt2ymVd <named list [40â€¦
#> 3 2019-08-16_chicken.pdf 18IVE8v-3jW_3iFiKuBNfb-yHFeG3Ri7_ <named list [39â€¦
#> 4 2019-08-16_chicken.txt 1O-VkK3hTTkM5hHzWAhqBOnbBqX3avfWf <named list [39â€¦

What if you wanted to get a list back, because your downstream operations include yet more map()ing? Then you would use map2().

files_list <- map2(files, new_names, drive_rename)

Clean up

Our trashing function, drive_trash() is vectorized and can therefore operate on a multi-file dribble. We could trash these files like so:

drive_trash(files_dribble)

If youâ€™re absolutely sure of yourself and happy to do something irreversible, you could truly delete these files with drive_rm(), which is also vectorized:

drive_rm(files_dribble)

Finally â€“ and this is the code we will actually execute â€“ the easiest way to delete these files is to delete their enclosing folder.

drive_rm(folder)
#> Files deleted:
#>   * upload-into-me-article-demo: 1I3xJXlT4Jany4LywLKuV14z99cXa0zrO
